Confined Nine Months.

FARRELL*—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years. (There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1939.
JOSEPH SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of June, 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
George Spelt, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE SPELT . I live in Seymour-street, Euston-square. About twelve o'clock in the day of the 14th of June I was in Bridge-street—I saw the prisoner put his hand into my pocket, take my handkerchief out, and put it into his own—I took it from his pocket, and took him to the station.

JOHN EDWARD GLASCOCK (police-sergeant R 25.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clack's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

1940.
THOMAS KIRBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of April, 12 handkerchiefs, value 1l. 7s.; 18 yards of net, value 8s. 4d.; 180 yards of lace, value 5l.; 360 yards of quilting, value 1l. 1s. 6d.; and 12 pairs of cuffs, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of
Richard Groncock and others.

WILLIAM OSBORNE . I am in the service of Richard Groncock—he has two partners—they are warehousemen, in Bow Churchyard. We have customers of the name of Pearce and Woodward, at Taunton—on Saturday the 30th of April, a person came from their firm to purchase goods—I sold some goods, consisting of two cards, of one sort of blonde lace, twenty-four cards of another sort, three pieces of thread lace not placed on cards, and twelve handkerchiefs—after I had sold them I gave them to Hill to be entered.

BENJAMIN HILL . I am apprentice at Messrs. Groncock's and others. On the 30th of April some goods were purchased by Pearce and Wood
ward, and handed to me by Osborn—I put them into a basket, and took them to the entering-room—Mr. Hibberd entered them.

JAMES HIBBERD . I am assistant at the prosecutor's. On the 30th of April, Hill brought me some goods in a basket—I called them over to the clerk, and saw them entered in the book—they were then put into paper, and delivered to John Hill.

JOHN HILL . I am in the service of Messrs. Groncock. I received the parcel—I put it into brown paper, and directed it to "Pearce and Wood
ward, Taunton," and delivered it to Charles Garland, to take it to Shar
land's, in Bishopsgate-street, to go to Taunton.

CHARLES GARLAND . I am a carman. I received a brown paper parcel to go to Pearce and Woodward, at Taunton—I placed it, with other par
cels, in my cart—I went with it to go to Bishopsgate-street—I had occa
sion to call at a house in Leadenhall-street, for eight or ten minutes—when I came out I missed this parcel.

GEORGE TREW . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner on the 5th of May—some policemen remained on the prisoner's premises till the 7th—on that morning I examined the premises, and found these two cards of lace and blonde in a little box behind the counter—I took them to Mr. Osborne, at Messrs. Groncock's.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. At what time did you take the prisoner? A. About nine o'clock in the morning—he was in custody when I found these things.

WILLIAM OSBORNE
re-examined. These are some of the articles which were put into Messrs. Pearce and Woodward's parcel.

(James Veitch, wholesale haberdasher, Noble-street, Cheapside; Hussey Chapman, Manchester warehouseman, Hart-street, Wood-street; William Matthews, linen-draper, Bishop's Stortford; James Butcher, haberdasher, Greenwich; Richard Banton, Wood-street, Cheapside; and—Morley, Manchester warehouseman, Wood-street, gave the prisoner a good cha
racter.)
GUILTY . Aged 43.

1941.
THOMAS KIRBY was again indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 1st of April, of an evil-disposed person, 361bs. weight of worsted, value 3l.; 360 sheets of wadding, value 2l. 16s.; 576 yards of wire ribbon, value 5s. 4d.; 860 yards of stay-binding, value 8s. 3d.; 596 pieces of tape, value 34l.; 34 pairs of gloves, value 2l. 8s.; and 25 gross of buttons, value 2l. 10s.; the goods of
William Hutchinson; well knowing them to have been stolen.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Abra
ham George.

FREDERICK PIGGOTT . I am in the service of Leaf and Company, of Old Change, London. William Hutchinson, of Reading, is a customer of my master's—I received an order for goods on the 30th of March, to be sent to Mr. Hutchinson—I selected a part of the goods, three dozen balls of worsted, thirty dozen of wadding, and twenty or thirty gross of ribbon wire, some tape, stay-binding, and some gloves—I took them to the order-room, to be entered in the journal—Mordant was engaged in the order-room—it was his duty to enter them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you venture to swear posi
tively to these things? A. Certainly not—Leaf and Co. are in a large way of business—they have bought stocks in cases of bankruptcy.

WILLIAM MORANT . I am in the service of Leaf and Co.—I remember an order for goods from Mr. Hutchinson, of Reading—some goods were brought me by Piggott—I called them over to the clerk of the books, and delivered them to Swamell the packer.
EDWIN FREDERICK WINSTON . I am in the service of Leaf and Co. I was at that time clerk of the books—I remember entering this order—I saw no more of the goods after they had been sold and entered.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you recollect anything of the order, or do you only find there are entries in the book made by yourself? A. Yes.

HENRY SWAMELL . I am packer in this establishment. I received from Morant a parcel of goods for Hutchinson—I put it into a wrapper, and directed it for "William Hutchinson, Reading"—it was delivered to Virgin, the carman, to be taken to Gerard's Hall.
WILLIAM VIRGIN . I am carman to Leaf and Co. I received a packet addressed to Hutchinson, at Reading, from Swamell, on the 30th of March—I took it to the office at Gerrard's Hall, and left it there.

JONAS CHBNY . I am porter at the wagon-office at Gerrard's Hall. On the 30th of March I received a package addressed to "William Hutchin
son, Reading"—I weighed it on the 31st of March, saw it loaded on the wagon, and helped to bind it—the wagon started for Reading about three o'clock in the afternoon—the package was in it then.

THOMAS SHEPHERD . I am wagoner for Reading. On the 31st of March I saw a truss safe in the wagon to go to Reading—I cannot read—it was placed on the corner behind, and was fastened with a rope—I met somebody near Cranford-bridge, I asked for a light, and then missed the package, which was safe when I went out of Brentford.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How many parcels were in the wagon? A. I cannot say.

GEORGE TREW (police-constable H 125.) I went to the prisoner's pre
mises on the 5th of May, at half-past nine o'clock, and took him—I searched the premises in his presence, and found thirty dozen of wadding under the counter—I asked how he got it—he said he bought it of a man who had lately gone out of business—I asked who the man was—he said I was no Magistrate, he should not answer that question—some of the policemen remained on the premises for nine days—I was thereon the 10th of May—I continued searching, and found some wire-ribbon, some gloves, and some other things—I have had them in my possession ever since.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you not take possessipn of the house itself? A. Yes, by the direction of Mr. Lewis, the inspector, the shop was shut up—the prisoner's wife was there on the 5th—I do not

know whether she was on the 10th—there were two men there at night, and two in the day—I did not take the key of the house—I do not be
lieve the key was taken.
WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (police-constable R 202.) I was at the search on the 10th—I found six bags of worsted-balls, thirty-six roll of stay-binding, and fifty-eight packets of tape.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you sleep in the house? A. No—I cannot say that the key was taken.

FREDERICK PIGGOTT
re-examined. This tape docs not tally in quan
tity with what I put up—I put up between fifty and seventy dozen—between fifty and sixty are found—they are the same Nos. and de
scription—the wadding is the same in quality and description and number—there were large and small put up for Hutchinson—these bills of worsted are of the same make, and the same sort of goods, and one of the bags is numbered with a "3," which is the same writing as we usually have in our stock, but they come ready written—these balls are about the same quantity.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. With all that, you do not swear to them? A. I do not—we send out enormous packages of these goods.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(There were four other indictments against the prisoner.)

1942.
THOMAS HOLMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of June, 1 pair of shoes, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
John Beckford, in a cer
tain port of entry and discharge.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1943.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of June, 1 pair of trowsers, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Scarnell.

THOMAS SCARNELL . I am a general salesman, and live in Grosvenor-row, Pimlico. I had this pair of trowsers outside on the 15th of June—I missed them—in consequence of information, I went after the prisoner, and found them under his arm—he said a boy gave them to him—they had the ticket on, and the pins in them—they are mine.

JAKE WILKINS . I saw the prisoner take the trowsers from the prose
cutor's shop—I gave information.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1944.
JAMES LABURN was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of June, 2 printed books, value 5s., 6d., the goods of
Mary Ann Wilton.
ELIZA RILEY . I am the wife of James Riley, and live with my mother, Mary Ann Wilton, who keeps a stationer's shop in Jamaica-terrace. On the 15th of June I lost two hymn-books from the window.
JAMES BARELAY . I produce these books. I caught the prisoner on the 15th of June, running from the shop with them.

Prisoner. I was looking into the shop—a boy came to the door, and asked me to hold them while he tied them up—he saw the gentleman running across the road, and ran away. Witness. There were other boys with him—they were not all running together.
JANE BARELAY . I was looking out of window, and saw the prisons leave
the others, and get into the shop, put his hand into the window, and take
the books.
Prisoner. I did not take them, a little boy did.

GUILTY.* Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

1945.
CORNELIUS SULLIVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of June, 4 1/2 lbs. weight of lead, value 8d., the goods of
Edward Sayers, in a certain port of entry and discharge.

JOHN LEITH . I am chief mate of the barque James Cruikshanks. in the West India Docks. The prisoner came on board on the afternoon of the 14th of June, between four and five o'clock—I was on the quay—I saw him walk from the larboard side on the deck towards the starboard—I followed, and as I went to the gangway, he met me, and went over the side again—I heard from those on board that he had something with him—he ran round the course of the sheds, and heaved something into the shed, then came and wished me to search him—I went to the place, and saw this lead picked up—it was the apron of a gun—it came from the star board
side of the deck—it is the property of Captain Edward Sayers.

GEORGE GORDON . I was on board, and saw the prisoner take something off the gun, and gave information to the carpenter, who told the mate—I saw the apron was gone from the gun, and I had seen the prisoner kneel
ing on the gun—this is the lead—it is used for the apron of the gun.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming there; I passed by the ship; a man opposite spoke to me, and about ten minutes afterwards the policeman came and said, "Halloo, come back;" I stood a moment, and then went; he overhauled me.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Two Months.

1946.
HANNAH EDMUNDS and
MARY NEWLAND were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June, 2 pewter pots, value 3s., the goods of
Peter Richard James.
PETER RICHARD JAMES . I am a victualler, and live in Charles-street, Berkley-square—these two pots are mine.

CHARLES DAVIS (police-constable C 47.) About half-past two o'clock in the morning of the 14th of June I was on duty in Hayes-mews, Berkley-square—I saw Newland take these two quart pots from the chill of a stable window—she ran round from the Mews in the direction of Berkley-square—I took her—Edmunds was in Charles-street, not near enough. to see Newland—I asked Newland to give me the pots that she had just stolen from the window—she gave them to me—Edmunds was there in company with her—they directly ran away—Edmunds was not there when Newland took them.
Newland's Defence. I was out with Edmunds to look after a servant; we saw the pots, and thought we would take care of them till the morning, and the publicans would give us a few halfpence.

EDMUNDS—
NOT GUILTY .

NEWLAND—
GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined Three Months.

1947.
HANNAH EDMUNDS and
MARY NEWLAND were again indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June, 1 pewter pot, value 10d., the goods of
Samuel Birley; 1 pewter pot, value 10d., the goods of
George Bevans and another; and 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
James Hooper .
SAMUEL BIRLEY . I am a victualler, in Holies-street, Hanover-square, I lost a pewter pot—this is mine.
GEORGE BEVANS . I have a partner, and live in Stafford-street. I lost a pint pot—this is mine.
JAMES HOOPER . I am a publican, in Shepherd's-market. I have lost this pot.

CHARLES DAVIS . I am a policeman. Edmunds ran away—I saw her put down a quart pot by the Marquis of Lansdown's gate, in Berkley. square, and cross the corner of the square—I saw her put down another one—I did not see Newland do any thing.
Edmunds' Defence. I took up the pots in hopes the gentlemen would give us something in the morning.
(Edmunds received a good character.)

EDMUNDS—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months. NEWLAND—
NOT GUILTY .

1948.
MATILDA CONNOLLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of June, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 guard-chain, value 16s.; and 1 handker
chief, value 4s.; the goods of
William Sprake, from his person.

WILLIAM SPRAKE . I am a pot-boy, and live in George-street. St. Giles. On the 2nd of June, about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon, I called at Bainbridge-street to see a friend—I saw the prisoner there—I asked her if George was at home, meaning the person she lived with—she said no—we had something to drink—I then went out by myself, for two boon and a half or three hours—I then returned there, as I wished to see George—I saw the prisoner again—she asked if my watch was safe—I said it was—she said it would be better for me to give it up to her, to give to the land
lady to take care of—I said I was quite capable of taking care of it myself—she would insist on taking it, and took it out of my pocket, took the guard off my neck, and the silk handkerchief out of my cap, and went out—I had had a little to drink, but I knew what I was about, and was capable of taking care of myself—she returned to the room in two or three minutes, and I asked if she had left my watch with the landlady—she said, "Yes," and I was satisfied—she then went out—I asked if she was going for George—she said, "Yes," but, instead of that, she fastened me in the room, and left word not to let me out—I afterwards gave her into custody—my watch and handkerchief have not been found.

BRIDGET PRENDERGAST . I was staying with a person in the next room at this house—the prisoner showed me a handkerchief the same evening—I heard her tell the prosecutor that she would take the watch round to Mrs. Sparrow, the landlady—the prisoner was drunk, and I called out, "Don't take the watch to Mrs. Sparrow"—she and the prosecutor had been together, and drinking—they passed as brother and sister—I told her she had better leave the watch with Ann—that was the person I was staying with.
JOSEPH SMALLEY (police-constable K 175.) I took the prisoner on the 3rd of June—I told her it was for stealing a watch in St. Giles's—she said she had not been in St. Giles's for a fortnight.
Prisoner's Defence. I have not seen it.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Four Months.

1949.
GEORGE WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of June 11lbs. weight of mutton, value 7s., the goods of
Alfred Underwood.

ALFRED UNDERWOOD . I am a butcher, and live in William-street, Westminster. About a quarter past eleven o'clock, on the evening of the 11th of June, I was in my shop—I had a leg of mutton there—I saw the prisoner take it off the rail, and run off—I ran and overtook him—he dropped it on the road—a woman picked it up.
Prisoner. He said he would not know his mutton hut he heard the book drop. Witness. No—I said I was satisfied it was mine, but was more confirmed by hearing the hook drop.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1950.
EBENEZER WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of April, 3 decanters, value 5s., the goods of
John Curtis.

JOHN CURTIS . The prisoner has been paying his addresses to my daugh
ter for some time. In consequence of what she told me, and having tome duplicates put into my hand, I looked over my stock, and missed some decanters—these are them.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Is your daughter here? A. I believe she is—she has not resided with me for several days—I have not spoken to her since last Friday.

LOUISA CURTIS . The prisoner has been paying his addresses to me for tome months—I received a letter from him, a week ago, containing some duplicates, which I produced to my father—I had authorized the prisoner to take these decanters, and I knew they were out of the house—I was so agitated when I was before the Magistrate, I did not know what I said—I have some recollection of his taking the decanters"
NOT GUILTY .

1951.
AMBROSE BALL was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May, 1 sack, value 2s., the goods of
John Trulock and another, his masters; and
SAMUEL WRIGHT HILL
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS TRULOCK . I am in partnership with my brother John; we are corn-merchants and factors; at Albion-wharf, Old Ford. Ball was our carman—we had no other regular carman—by chance we might send out another—I have seen a corn-sack produced—it is our property, I am certain of it—it is one of some I bought in December—Ball had no authority to deliver it to Hill or to any person whatever—he had no business with this sack on the 27th of May—he might have taken sacks of this description in his business—he had to deliver beans that day, which he did, and they might be in sacks of this kind—he had no right to take anything but beans that day.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many sacks had you of this description? A. thousand.

MATTHEW YOUNG . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Mile-end-road. About seven o'clock in the morning, on the 26th or 27th of May, I was standing at Canham's door, which is opposite to where the prisoner Hill lives—he is a corn-chandler—I saw a wagon come up driven by Ball, Mr. Trulock's carter—it stopped opposite Hill's door, and a man came out
of Hill's, but I could not say who it was—Ball took a sack off his wagon and put it on the shaft, and the man who came out of Hill's took the sack off the shaft.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. This was done openly in the motn
ing? A. Yes—I had seen Hill before, but I do not know that it was him.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Were you on the opposite side? A. Yes—the road is wide, but not so wide but that I could see Mr. Tru
lock's name on the wagon—it was about a fortnight or three weeks after, before I gave any information—I have never bad any dealing with Mr. Trulock—I swear that Ball was there—I did not go to him, nor speak to him.

THOMAS EDWARD CANHAM . I am a corn-dealer, and live in Mile-end-road. I was in company with Young on the morning of the 26th or 27th of May, about half-past seven o'clock, at my door—I saw Mr. Trnlock's wagon come up to Hill's door—Hill came out and took a full sack of something of the carman—there were other sacks in the wagon—I men
tioned it some days afterwards.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You carry on the same business as Hill does? A. Yes, and have for four years or four years and a half—I was talking to Mr. Young about a sample of beans.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was this done immediately? A. Thi sack was given down as soon as the wagon stopped—I did not mention this, because Mr. Hill was a neighbour and in the same line of business.

JAMES PHILLIPS (police-constable K 20.) I received charge of Bali at Mr. Trulock's wharf, on Friday evening last—Mr. Trulock said to him, "You have been robbing me"—he said, "I don't know what you mean, I know nothing at all about it"—I then went with Mr. John Trulock to Hill's—Hill was not at home, but when he came in, Mr. Trulock said to him, "You have got some property in your house belonging to me"—Hill said, "If this sack is yours you can have it"—the sack was then three-parts full of peas—Hill said he could account for where he got the peas—the sack was lying on the floor, without anything to bide it—the top was turned down, I could just see the T on it.
Cross-examined by Mr. PAYNE. Q. Was it not just inside the door, against the counter? A. Yes—any person going by could see it—I did not see any ticket on the peas, but they were standing openly.

JOHN TRULOCK . I am in partnership with the prosecutor. Mr. Knight is a customer of ours—when we send him beans they are gene
rally in his own sacks—on this occasion we sent him some in his own sacks—Hill was not a customer of ours—no man has a right to take any
thing of ours off our premises, without he has a note to show of it, written by our clerk—I had no regular carman but Ball—I occasionally send a man out with a single horse, but Ball had four horses.

MR. GREEN. I am clerk at Lambeth-street, Office. I took the depo
sitions in this case—this is the Magistrate's signature to this deposition.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you quite sure this was taken in the presence of the Magistrate? A. No, it was said in a room adjoining the office—it was then read to the prisoner in the presence of the Magistrate—(read)—the prisoner Ball says, "All I have got to say is I never de
livered a sack of corn to this man in my life, or any other sack; the man must be mistaken in the man that drove the wagon at the time, if it was

so; Hill says, "I never had any such sack from Mr. Trulock; I had other sacks, and this one came from one of my customers in Limehouse-field, in February last; about five weeks ago I took a sack of barley-field, of my shop, and I emptied these pass in to this sack of Mr. Trulock's; this sack never was dropped at my door; I wish God may strike me down dead if ever it was; it is very common for corn-dealers to have other people's sacks."
(The prisoner Hill received a good character.)

BALL—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Judgment Respited.

HILL—
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Nine Months.

1952.
LOUISA WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of June, 1 watch, value 1l., the goods of
Sarah Elizabeth Deane.

SARAH ELIZABETH DEANE . On Friday, the 10th of June, about one o'clock in the day, the prisoner came to my house to inquire for lodgings—I am sure it was her—my watch hung on the mantel-piece—the pri
soner requested some water, and I desired her to follow me to get it—after she was gone I missed the watch—this now produced is it.
HENRY MALLAM . I am in the service of a pawnbroker. On the 10th of Jane, this watch was pawned for 8s., I believe by the prisoner, about five o'clock.

Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the watch, nor this witness; I never was in the pawnbroker's shop; I do not know where it is; I was at my aunt's from ten o'clock in the morning, till six in the evening,
GUILTY .** Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1953.
ANN PICKETT and
ROSE HAMILTON were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June, 1 purse, value 1s.; 1 ring, value 8s.; 4 sovereigns, and 5 shillings; the property of
John Cook, from his person.

JOHN COOK . I live in Somers-place, Chelsea. On the 14th of June I was going home, and two females spoke to me—I then turned out of the Fulham-road, to go home, and one of the females walked by the side of me, and pressed against me, making propositions that I rejected—the other girl staid at the top of the turning, and said something—the one who was by my side said, "My sister calls me"—she went up to her, and they both went away—I then missed my purse, containing four sovereigns and five shillings—this is my purse, and my ring, which I much value.

Cross-examined by ME. CHARNOCK. Q. Where had you been pasting the evening? A. With a friend in Cook's-ground, Chelsea—I was sober—I do not know who the females were—one was a tall girl, and the other short—the short one followed me down, and pressed against me.

EDWARD DEVALL (police-constable V 48.) I was on duty near So
merset-place, and saw the two prisoners pass me, running—in a few minutes the prosecutor came up, and said he had been robbed of a purse and money—in the course of the same night I went to the prisoners' room, and found them in bed—I saw this purse found on the bed in the room by Kimber.

HENRY KIMBER (police-constable V 20.) I went to where the pri
soners were—I told them they were charged on suspicion of stealing a purse, with four sovereigns and some silver, in the Fulham-road, Little
Chelsea—they denied having been there at all—I then saw Pickett hand the purse on the bed to the other side to which she had been sleeping.

PICKETT—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

HAMILTON—
GUILTY . Aged 21
Confined Three Months.

1954.
EDWARD JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of June, 1 pick-axe, value 2s., the goods of
Edward Hayes; and 1 shovel value 1s., the goods of
Edward Kennedy.

EDWARD HAYES . On the 10th of June, I had a pick-axe in Ton
bridgestreet, where I was at work—I lost it between twelve and one o'clock—this is it.
EDWARD KENNEDY . I was at work there—I went to dinner, and left my shovel there—it was gone when I returned—this is it.
THOMAS BROWN . About one o'clock that day the prisoner came and offered me this pick-axe and shovel—I bought them of him—be came again on the 14th, and from what I had heard I sent for a policeman,
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the road, and a man came and said, "Will you buy a pick-axe and shovel?" I gave him 9d., and he took it.

GUILTY.*—
Confined Nine Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1955.
JOHN THOMAS was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 7 spoons, value 15s., the goods of
Benjamin King.

ELIZABETH BLAKE . I am in the service of Benjamin King, of Minor-place, Chelsea. On the 17th of June, I found the prisoner in the kitchen—he walked out of the area—I went up, and gave an alarm—the prisoner was brought back with these spoons, which are my master's.

JOHN MOSLET TURNER . I heard a cry, and saw the prisoner running—I followed him, and saw him throw these spoons out of his hand, over a fence, into a timber-yard—I got them, and took them to Mrs. filake.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1956.
BENJAMIN HEATH was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Mills.
HARRIET MILLS . I am the daughter of Thomas Mills. I hang out a sheet in a private yard, on a line, on the 17th of June—I missed it about half-past eleven o'clock in the morning—this is it.
MARK WEBSTER . I am a private watchman. On the morning of the 17th, at half-past eleven o'clock, I met the prisoner with this sheet—I took him—he resisted and kicked me.
Prisoner. I found it lying on the timber in the yard—I am very sorry—I was in great distress.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1957.
MARY PURDY was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 2 lb. 14 oz. weight of mutton, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
William Bot
trill.

JOHN GULLARD . I am servant to Mr. Bottrill, butcher, of Rochester-row, Westminster. On the 17th of June, I saw the prisoner outside our shop—she took the mutton from the board, and my master took it away from her, when she had got about thirty yards—I saw him take it from
under her cloak—she said she was very sorry, and did not know how she came to do it.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Had she bought any thing? A. Yes, one piece—I am sure she did not buy this piece—my mistress is not here, nor my master—the prisoner had paid my mistress for one piece, which came to sixpence—that piece was in her basket—I have been a witness in the Old Court before—I got more than 1l. 4s. by that—I did not say that I liked such jobs as these, to my knowledge—I cannot swear that I did not—the prisoner's daughter and sons were joking with me over the way in a public-house, and I said I did not know whe
ther there was a God or not, as I bad never seen him—I said that, be
cause I was asked the question—I was asked a great many questions by the whole of them—they had been trying to make me tipsy—I have known the prisoner to come to my master as a customer for four years—the lives in the neighbourhood—I saw my master yesterday rooming—he said he did not wish to prosecute the prisoner—he said yesterday that he did not want to have any thing to do with it.
WILLIAM CORNISH (police-constable B 35.) I took the prisoner—she said she was very sorry for what she had done, and hoped the prosecutor would forgive her.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she not say she did not mean to steal it? A. She said she did not intend to steal any thing—I found 1s. 6d. on her.
NOT GUILTY .

1958.
WILLIAM BRUMMELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 1 pair of boots, value 7s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 5s.; and 1 shoe, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Wood.

THOMAS WOOD . I live in Brunswick-place," West Hackney. I am a boot and shoemaker. On the 17th of June, about eight o'clock in the evening, I went out, leaving my shop in the care of my wife, and Sophia Francois—when I came back I missed two pair of boots, one pair of shoes, and one odd shoe—I have seen the pair of shoes since, they are mine.

SOPHIA FRANCOIS . I was sitting in the parlour—I turned round and saw a man going out of the shop—I cried out, and ran down the steps—the policeman caught the prisoner, and brought him back in a few minutes.
ROBERT PEARCE (police-constable, N 71) I saw the prisoner running, and he dropped these shoes by my side.
Prisoner. I did not have them.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1959.
JOHN TERRY and
WILLIAM ALLEN were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June, 1 basket, value 10d.; and 1 jar, value 2d; the goods of
Thomas Worthington.

THOMAS WORTHINGTON . I live in Queen-gardens, Brompton. On the 14th of June, I had a basket containing a small jar, at a public-house at Knightsbridge—I left it for a few minutes, and when I came back it was gone—these are them.
WILLIAM PRYOR . I was at the public-house, on the 14th of June, and saw Allen come out of the house, followed by Terry, who had a basket to his hand similar to this.
RICHARD REED . Terry brought the basket and jar to me for sale—I gave him 6d. for them.

TERRY—
GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

ALLEN—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1960.
CHARLES RICHARDSON was indicted
for feloniously as
saulting
James Robert Hartley, and
Julian Hartley, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of a Common Assault. Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1961.
JOHN HUBBARD was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
William Martin, with intent, &c, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 60.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1962.
JOHN THURSTON was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
John Mullins.

EPHRAIM GWALTER . I am a baker, and live at Plaistow. On the 30th of May, I was outside the Coach and Horses there, and saw the de
ceased John Mullins, who I knew by sight, standing sparring through the window at the prisoner—he was not within reach—they were both in liquor—the deceased called the prisoner a b—thing, and said he was no use either for fighting or for work—the landlord came out, and ordered Mullins away—he refused to go until he had seen the prisoner—the land
lord sent the prisoner out—the prisoner came out and said something to Mullins, who immediately stripped to his skin—the prisoner pulled off his jacket, and they sparred at each other—a man named Smith tried to make it up between them—at last they got to fighting in the road—they each had a second—the deceased struck the first blow—the prisoner struck him again underneath the left ear, and he fell—that was the only blow—in falling he struck himself at the back of the head, and was taken into the public-house yard insensible—he was carried to his brother's house on a man's back—I afterwards saw him dead.
Cross-examined by MR. PBENDERGAST. Q. It was entirely provoked by the deceased? A. It was, quite.

THOMAS FLOWER . I saw the quarrel in the public-house—the deceased began it—he provoked the prisoner very much indeed to fight, and used very bad language—he said he was no man at all—he was nothing but a thing, he could neither fight nor work, and he aggravated him very much—the deceased went out and stripped, and told the prisoner to come out—he said, "I do not want any thing to say to you"—he threw the window up, and said if he did not come out, he would pull him out by his snout—he asked him again, "Are you coming out?"—he said, "I do not want any thing to do with you"—he said, "If you do not come out I will fetch you out"—he looked over my left shoulder, and tried to reach hold of him—he threw both the windows open, and sparred at him—a boy pulled
them down—he threw them up again to catch hold of him to pull him out to fight—I did not go out of the house, and did not see the fight.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you known the prisoner? A. From a child—I never knew him to be quarrelsome.

CATHERINE MULLINS . The deceased was my husband—he left home at five o'clock the morning this happened—he was quite well then—I saw him next at half-past eight or nine at night, at his brother's—he was not insensible then—I saw a cut on his head—it was bleeding—he got his speech, and came to his senses on the Thursday following, but lost them again on Friday morning—he died last Wednesday week—his name was John—Mr. Beale the surgeon saw him.

WILLIAM WELLER . I am a watchman, at Plaistow. I was at the Coach and Horses there on the 3rd of May, and saw the prisoner and Mullins in the tap-room—Mullins told the prisoner to come out, and he would fight him—I afterwards saw them fighting in the road—I saw the prisoner strike one blow, and the deceased fall.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see whether the deceased struck too? A. No—I cannot tell—I think he was provoking the prisoner for about a quarter of an hour in various ways, using very had language to him—he stopped in the house some time after the deceased went out, and I saw the deceased push up the window, still provoking the prisoner—I have known the prisoner from a child, and never saw him in any row or trouble before—he is no fighter.

JOHN EVANS BEALE . I am a surgeon, and live at Plaistow. I saw the deceased first on Monday, the 6th of June—he had then been ill a week—he had symptoms of effusion of blood, or fluid on the brain, pro
ducing convulsive spasms and fits—he was sensible, but only at times—when I first saw him, I told him to put out his tongue, which he did—he appeared sensible then, but that morning he had two or three fits—he died on the 8th—I made a post mortem exam
ination—on removing the skull cap, I found lying on the left hemi
sphere of the brain, from one to two ounces of coagulated blood, between the pia mater, and dura mater, which accounted for his death—he had a small wound at the back of his head, it was nearly well—there was a bit of plaster on it, which I took off—I did not apply anything fur
ther—there was not much concussion, and no external swelling—there were evidently several other blows on the back of his head—I apprehend that concussion was the cause of the extravasation of blood—I consider a blow or fall was the cause of it—I do not know that a blow under the left ear would produce it without a fall, but accompanied with a fall it would—such a blow and fall as has been described would be sufficient to account for what I saw, and the man being partially intoxicated.

Cross-examined. Q. You could not trace the extravasation to the wound at the back of the head? A. It led me to know that he had had a severe blow on his head—there was no fracture—the blow was between the hemispheres of the brain—the blood was all in one hemisphere—ex
travasation may occur without violence—it is more likely to occur during intoxication—I do not think he could have recovered under any circum
stances—the extravasation had most likely existed for some days, but I cannot state positively how long.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—Strongly recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Week.

1963.
THOMAS CLARK was indicted
for assaulting
Harriet Howe, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of an assault.—
Confined Six Months.

1964.
MARY ANN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of June, 12 yards of ribbon, value 7s., and 1 pair of gloves, value 4d.; the goods of
Richard Turner Hickes; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

1965.
EDWARD GEORGE JEFFORD was indicted
for a misde
meanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1966.
JOHN DEANE was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of April, 1 purse, value 1s. 6d.; 1 half-crown, 3 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 2 groats, the property of
Phillis Day; and 1 pair of breeches, 2l. 15s.; 1 pair of gaiters, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1l.; 1 hat, value 1l.; 1 coat, value 4l.; the goods of Thomas Scurr Womersley, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

1967.
WILLIAM STANTON was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1968.
JOHN MILLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of June, 1 pair of boots, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2d.; the goods of
Robert Papworth; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 54.—
Confined Three Months.

1969.
MICHAEL DONOVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of June, 1 tame fowl, price 2s.; the property of
Edward Wolf; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

1970.
WILLIAM WEBB was indicted
for stealing, on the l 7th of May, 1 pair of shoes, value 5s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 2 watchguards, value 6d.; 2 shillings, and 2 pence; the property of
William Merritt.

WILLIAM MERRITT . I live at Deptford, the prisoner lodged in the same house for a few days, and slept in the same room with me. On Whit Tuesday morning I missed the things and money stated, from my pocket in the bed-room—they were my own—I have no father—the pri
soner was the first that went out that morning—he knew I had some money, for he had seen me give change with it—this watch-chain now produced is mine—I know it by a join in the middle—I kept it in my pocket in the bed-room.

Prisoner. He bought that chain on Whit Sunday for a halfpenny, and a thrush-bird for 4d.; he gave me the chain to look at; while I was look
ing at it the parlour bell rang, and he went away, leaving the chain with me. Witness. I did not, for I had it in my pocket next morning.

ROBERT HORNSBY . I am a constable at Seen, near Newbury, in Berkshire. On the 25th of May I apprehended the prisoner at Newbury, on another charge—in searching him I found in his pocket, among other things, this chain—I said, "Halloo! what do you call this?"—he said, "Oh, it is nothing but an old chain that I found on the road"—he said nothing about Merritt having given it to him.
Prisoner's Defence. I forgot that at the time. Three men lodged in the third floor besides me. I got up in the morning, and the landlady let me out. I had no bundle, or anything in my hand.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1971.
WILLIAM WEBB was again indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of May, 2 chaise-springs, value 1l. 15s.; the goods of
Thomas Gower, his master.

THOMAS GOWER . I am a coachmaker, at Greenwich. The prisoner was in my employ for about a week—I had a pair of chaise springs in my shop—the prisoner said he knew a person at Woolwich, where he had been at work, that wanted a pair of springs, and he repeatedly asked me, in the course of the week, if I would dispose of them to his friend—I said they were disposed of to another person, which they were—but as the per
sons did not come for them, and thinking that the sale of these would enable me to make a new pair, on Whit Monday, the 16th of May, I trusted the prisoner with them to take to Woolwich and show his friend—he said he did not know the man's name—the prisoner had repeatedly asked, in the coarse of the week, to buy them himself, which I refused, and also refused his taking them to Woolwich, till the Monday morning—they were worth 35s.—I have a copy of the account which I gave him with the springs—I did not tell him what to do if the man did not pay for them—he took them from me, in the full confidence that the man would take them at that price—it was to be a ready money transaction, of course.

Prisoner. I worked for Mr. Gower nine days and three-quarters, but could get no wages, and understanding these springs were for sale, I asked him if he would sell me them; he said a person had been about them; I asked him for money; he gave me 4d. and 6d. at a time, in the course of the week; on Saturday night he gave me half-a-crown, and said, if I would call in about an hour, he would give me some more; hearing that he had deceived so many of his men, I said, if he would give me another half-crown I would make shift till Monday; when I went on Monday he said, "I think you shall take these springs, and bring me back a few shillings, as I am very short this morning." Witness. I deny the whole of it—I had paid him his wages, all but a trifle—he only worked for me four days and a quarter—he was to have 18s. a-week—he received 6s. 4d. in the course of the week, and 5s. on Saturday night—when he came to work on Monday morning I gave him the springs to take to his friend at Woolwich—he said he should be home between nine and ten o'clock, and I never saw him till he was apprehended—I gave information to the police, and they put it in the "Hue and Cry."
ROBERT HORNSBY . I am a constable of Speen. On the 25th of May

I went to Reading after the prisoner, seeing his description in the"✗ and Cry"—I said, "I want you for a robbery at Mr. Gower's, at Green
wich, for a pair of coach-springs"—he said, "Oh, he can't hurt me for that, I bought the springs; in fact, he gave them to me to sell, and I sold them to a man on the road, in a horse and cart, but I don't know the man, nor where he lives."

Prisoner's Defence, Mr. Gower agreed to give me 27s. a-week, and I only received 9s. 6d.; a man who lived with him heard us talk about my buying the springs, and that man told me he could not get his money; he said, “Mind, he is very deep, if you can't get your money buy the springs of him." I was up all Friday night, not being able to get money for a lodging; when I went on Monday morning, he said, "Halloo, young fellow, I thought I had lost you;" I said, "I thought you had no money for me;" he said, "Oh, I can always squeeze out some for you;" and afterwards he said he had none, and gave me 8d. The Magistrate said he believed my statement was true, as he had been there before, trying to cheat his men, who had summoned him for their wages, and put him in the court for it. He told me he had a boy coming to work for him; and when the boy came, he said, "Oh, I am not going to work for him; they tell me I shall never get any money." He had no money to give me on the Monday morning, and he said if I had a friend to buy the springs, I should have them. I met a man on the road, and he said, "Those springs would look well under my cart;" I said, "You can have them," and I sold them. I was going home to get work where I served my time. You could buy such springs for 30s. anywhere; 1l. 15s. is due to me.

THOMAS GOWER
re-examined. All I can make out due to him 1s. 5d.—he told me himself that he only worked four days and a quarter—I em
ployed several men out of charity last winter, on condition that if I could not pay them all their wages, they would give me time, and work till the spring—they then wanted me to raise their wages, which I refused, and they summoned me—some I have paid, and some not—I suppose that is what the prisoner alludes to—I agreed to give him 18s. a-week when I could put him on work—I kept him a fortnight or three weeks at bay before I put him on—I gave him the springs to dispose of for me—he said he was sure the party would buy them, and I put the lowest price I could on them—he was not sent with them to hawk about—he said the person he was going to sell them to was a potato-merchant, in Pole-street, Wool
wich, which is three miles and a half from ray house—I took him by the hand, under the impression, from the respectable shops he had worked in, that he was a good workman, and I said I would be a friend to him, and make it a constant place—I gave him 8d. on the Friday, which was all the change I had in my pocket—he prejudiced the mind of the boy who came to work, because he wanted the place for a nephew of his own, and told me he had written to Bristol for him—I certainly never sold the prisoner the springs—he got them from me under the representation that there was a customer for them at Woolwich, and I authorized him to sell them to that customer—he asked me for money on the Monday morning, but I had no change—I had only a 5l. draft in my pocket—there was no one present at the conversation between the prisoner and myself about the springs.
Prisoner. He put the springs on my shoulder; there was a pair of shackles on them; he said, "Take them off, they will be worth 5s. to
me;" I got the wrench, and took off. Witness. I took them off myself—they would not be wanted with the springs, and they are always an additional charge.
GUILTY.* Aged 25.

1972.
FREDERICK THORNTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of May, 6 sovereigns and 10 shillings, the monies of
Joseph Cole, his master.

JOSEPH COLE . I am a stationer, and live in London-street, Green
wich—the prisoner was in my employment upwards of two years—I had him from his parents. On Saturday afternoon, the 14th of May, I gave him six sovereigns and ten shillings, to go to town and purchase some Sunday newspapers at the different news-offices—he generally brought them by the railroad—he did not return—next Monday he was brought to my house by my son—I asked what he had done with the money—he said, "I have none"—he had 12s. a-week—he always behaved well up to this time.

DANIEL MONYAHAN (police-constable R 184.) I took the prisoner into custody in London-street, Greenwich, and brought him to the station—I found on him a silver watch, a gold ring, a sovereign, five shillings, a fourpenny-piece, and 7d. in coppers.
MR. COLE re-examined. These do not quite account for the money—I understand he got some of his clothes out of pawn—he was bailed, and has surrendered to take his trial.

Prisoner. I am extremely sorry for what I have done, hut I had no felonious intent; I intended to make up the money in the course of the week, and pay my master. Witness. I understand that he belonged to a 6l. money-club; they pay so much a-week or month, and have a draw. (The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Confined Three Months.

1973.
JOHN WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of May, 561bs. weight of hay, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Morris, his master.

RICHARD MORRIS . I am the son of William Morris, of Lee, in Kent—the prisoner was in our service between two and three months, at 15s. a week. On the 31st of May he went with a wagon to town—I saw the wagon go out of the yard with a quantity of hay in it, which he had no right to have—in consequence of suspicion, I followed him, and saw him deliver the hay at the Rose, just by New Cross-turnpike—he remained there some time, and then drove away, leaving the hay behind him—I have since examined that hay, and it is of the same quality as the hay on our premises—it was a truss—I followed and overtook him after he left the Rose, and asked what he had done with the hay he had in his wagon—he said he had left it at the Rose to bait his horses on his return from London—I asked what quantity he had left—he said a small parcel, a quantity that he could put under his arm—I asked if he had not left any more—he said no—I said, "I am sure you are telling me a story, you left more"—he denied it again—I said, "I am convinced that you left a truss, for I saw you deliver it"—he denied it—I had seen him put it out into a rack which they feed the horses out of, and a bundle of hay besides

—I gave the hay in charge of a policeman—the small bundle was quite sufficient for the horses, with the corn he had, independent of the truss—they could not have eaten the truss in the time they would be gone—they left our yard at four in the afternoon, and would return about twelve—they had three nose-bags full of corn, besides a bushel of corn, the bundle of hay, and the truss.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. He had the charge of three horses? A. Yes—I was in the yard when he started—he saw me there—he went away, about a hundred yards, and I called him back to put a quarter of oats into the wagon to leave at Deptford—I saw the oats put into the wagon, and then saw the truss of hay—it was distinctly to be perceived—I was on the landing of the granary, and the wagon was imme
diately underneath, but I firmly believe that he did not know that I saw it—when he got to the Rose, he got up into the wagon, and I suppose ordered the man to bring the rack round to the wagon—I was not near enough to hear him—I remained at some distance—I saw the hay put into the rack—the rack was then moved to the side of the house—it was not put under cover—nothing passed between the prisoner and any one else—I waited till the wagon drove off—there was no occasion for his stop
ping at the Rose on his return—I never knew that he stopped there—when I came up to the Rose, a policeman was there, and witnessed the whole of it—I cannot swear to the hay, but I can swear it was taken out of our yard.

COURT. Q. Have you compared it with the hay on your father's pre
mises? A. Yes, next morning—I know it came out of one of the stacks in the stack-yard—we were cutting hay from that stack that same after
noon.

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable R 49.) On the 31st of May I re
ceived information, and watched the prisoner—I saw him at the Rose-he stopped the wagon, and called the ostler, who brought the rack—the pri
soner got up into the wagon, and put down a small bundle of bay, and a truss—he then got down, untwisted the two hay-bands, and the horses eat some of the truss—he went inside with the ostler, came out in about ten minutes, and went on—the bundle of hay was removed by the ostler to the side of the house, and put into another crib—I took the prisoner into custody next morning—I asked if he knew what I wanted him for—he said he did not—I said it was for stealing a truss of hay from his master's premises—he said he did not, what hay he had taken, he meant to bait his horses with, when he came back from London—I said, "Did not you see me?"—he said, "No"—I said, "I saw you deliver a truss of hay to the ostler, besides a small bundle"—he said he did not—the weight of the hay I took possession of, including two halters, with which we tied it up in
stead of the two bands, was 541bs.—the three horses had only fed on it ten minutes.

Cross-examined. Q. When did the ostler take the bundle? A. When he called for the crib, the bundle and the truss were put out—the small bundle was removed by the under ostler, and the truss was put before the horses—the small bundle was put into a rack by the side of the house—where no horses were feeding—none of it was removed inside—I returned to the public-house in two minutes—I only went off the bridge to see that he had no hay in his wagon, and when I returned I found the prosecutor

demanding his hay—the ostler had removed the rack to the side of the house—I did not ask the ostler any questions—I apprehended the under ostler next day—the upper ostler was there, but he took no part in the proceeding—horses may eat a good deal of hay in a quarter of an hour.

RICHARD MORRIS
re-examined. The wagon was going to Barclay's brewbouse for grains—it is six or seven miles from my house—we did not allow the men to take any hay at all—I should say three large horses might eat half a truss on their return from London—there was 10lbs. or 12lbs. of hay in the bundle, but they had considerably more than they could have eaten in their nose-bags, and corn besides, had they stopped out till eight or nine next morning—we had been robbed previous to this, and ever since then have refused the men having bay—it is unnecessary—a carter would sooner take corn than hay for his horses—I do not think I had spoken to the prisoner personally about it, as he was only two or three months in our service—my father hired him—he came from Mr. Egerton's service, with whom he lived five or six years; even if we did allow hay, this would be an unreasonable quantity—the horses had been in the stable baiting, three or four hours before they started—they would return between twelve and one in the night—when I first saw the hay in the wagon, I said nothing about it, because I was determined to see whe
ther he made a property of it or not.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Month.

1974.
JOHN THORNTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 2d., the goods of a man whose name is un
known, from his person.

RICHARD HILL (police-constable T 118.) On the 17th of May, be
tween eight and nine o'clock, I was on duty in Greenwich fair, and saw the prisoner attempt different persons' pockets—he went up to a gentle
man behind Richardson's show, put his left hand into the gentleman's pocket, lift it, put his right hand in, drew the handkerchief out, and put it under his waistcoat—I took hold of him, and took the handkerchief from under his waistcoat—I went, and asked the gentleman if he had lost his handkerchief—he put his hand into his pocket, and said be had—I told him to come to the station with me—he was coming, but there was a great rush, and I lost him—he did not come to the station.

Prisoner. As I was coming through the crowd I took the handker
chief off my neck; it is my own; he said he took it from my jacket pocket, and now he says from under my waistcoat. Witness. I took it from under his waistcoat.

HENRY FOWLER (police-constable E 111.) I saw the prisoner in Greenwich fair—he took hold of a gentleman's pocket, put his hand in, and took out this handkerchief—Hill laid hold of him, and took the hand
kerchief from him—I had noticed him before, following several gentlemen, apparently with that object—he took hold of two or three gentlemen's coats.
Prisoner. I was not five minutes in the fair. Witness. I saw him two hours before that.
Prisoner's Defence. It is my own handkerchief which I had on my neck; there is no mark on it.

RICHARD HILL
re-examined. Q. Was it in the middle of the crowd this happened? A. No, just on the outside, by Richardson's show—I was

behind him, looking over his shoulder at the time he put his hand into the pocket—he said at the time it was a yellow handkerchief—I found nothing on him but an old purse—I believe he had a handkerchief on his neck—I will not be certain—I spoke to the person directly in the prisoner's presence—he had no money whatever—he had not the handkerchief in his possession an instant before I took him—as soon as he put it under his waistcoat I took him—he had no time to examine whether it was marked or not—it is not marked—it was produced before the Magistrate—the inquiry was made there whether it had a mark, and he said it was a yellow handker
chief of his own.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1975.
JAMES PROCTER was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
William Willcox, on the 2nd of June, and stabbing, cutting, and wounding him in and upon the left shoulder, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM WILLCOX . I am a waterman, and work on the water, at Putney. I live in Coltman's buildings, Greenwich. On Thursday, the 26th of June, I was in the tap-room of the Red Lion—the prisoner was in the room—I threw some ale out of a glass towards the fire—it was not intentionally done—I think a little of it touched the prisoner—I had seen him before that—I had no quarrel with him—I did not intend to throw it over him—he ran towards me, I turned my back to him, and perceived a knife cut me in the back—my brother said he had a knife in his hand—I did not see it taken from him—I was wounded with it—it has got better now—I did not go to the hospital—the injury was not sufficient.
Prisoner. He threw the beer in my face; I was intoxicated at the time. Witness. I believe some persons had been chaffing him before I came in—I should be very sorry to hurt him.

GEORGE CAMPBELL . I saw Willcox throw about a table spoonful of ale out of his glass—I think some of it went on the prisoner's cheek—he instantly rushed between the tables, and began to hit him with his hand—we thought he was playing—nobody thought he had a knife in his hand till his brother said, "My God, he has got a knife in his hand"—Curtis instantly seized him, and took the knife out of his fist as he was going to make a jab at him—he said to me, "I have done it; I will go any where with you; I have done it, and must suffer the laws of my country for it"—he was handed over to the police.

HENRY KEEBLE . I am a surgeon. I examined the prosecutor, and found two wounds on one shoulder, and another on the loin—they were about an inch deep—I think the knife must have gone obliquely, which would diminish the depth—neither of them were severe, nor attended with any serious consequences—it was in a muscular part of the loin, and not followed by any inflammation—the knife produced would make such a wound.

GEORGE GOOD (police-constable R 2.) I apprehended the prisoner at the Red Lion—he appeared to have been drinking, and said he knew he had done it, and must suffer the laws of his country—I asked why he did it—he said he did not know that the prosecutor had done any thing to him to cause him to do so—a man named Curtis, I believe, gave me the knife produced—the prisoner said the man had never done him any hurt, and
he did not know why he did it—he is a Greenwich pensioner, and bears a very good character at the hospital.

Prisoner's Defence. My head is very bad; I have been under a surgeon at times; and when in liquor I lose myself entirely; I know nothing of taking the knife out of my pocket at all; it was like a dream to me; when I saw the deed was done it struck me with terror instantly.
GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 62.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.—
Confined One Year.

1976.
JOHN GOLLICHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of May, 4lbs. weight of leaden pipe, value 6d., the goods of
Sarah Shep
herd, and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, stating it not to be fixed; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES LAST (police-constable R 76.) On the 20th of May, between five and six o'clock in the morning, I was on duty in London-street, Greenwich. I saw the prisoner in Shepherd's-court—I followed him into the back of the premises—he got into a privy, and there I found a piece, of lead by the side of him—I asked how he came to be wet about the head and face—he said, "I don't know any thing about it"—I took the lead, and compared it with some near a doorway of Shepherd's premises, and am certain it had formed part of it—I had seen that pipe safe within half-an-hour before.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me break it? A. No, I saw you go from the spot it was taken from—you begged of me hard to let you go, and said you would never do so any more.

ANTHONY SHEPHERD . I am the son of Sarah Shepherd, a widow, and the landlady of the premises in question; it is her freehold—it is in Church-passage, Greenwich, about a street and a half from where the pri
soner was apprehended—the officer called on me—I went round the pre
mises, and found that a portion of the pipe had been broken off—I cannot tell whether the prisoner worked on the premises, as the house is in the occupation of a man named Doughty, an umbrella-maker.

GEORGE WILSON . I am a policeman. I produce a piece of pipe from the tank, where it was cut off—I have compared it with the other—it ap
pears to me to be part of the same.

JOSEPH LAST
re-examined. It was fixed to the tank, which was at the side of the wall in the passage, outside the house—it was fixed to the building.

GEORGE WILSON . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from the Deputy Clerk of the Peace at Maid
stone—(read)—I know the prisoner—I was present at his trial—he is the man described in the certificate.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1977.
JANE OLIVER was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of June, 1 pair of trowsers, value 7s. 6d., the goods of
John Harwood.

MARTHA HARWOOD . I live with my father, John Harwood, at Church
hill, Woolwich—he keeps a clothes-shop. On the 14th of June, about two o'clock, I noticed a piece of iron on which some clothes were moving, and saw the prisoner leaving the door, putting the trowsers under her arm—I followed her, and told her she had taken a pair of trowsers from the door—she said she had not—I said I saw her putting them under her arm
—she said a gentleman had just given them to her to carry—she refused to go back to the shop, and I gave her into custody.
Prisoner. Q. How far was I from the shop when you came np to me.
A. Between two and three yards—I am sure it was not above ten yards—when I first saw you moving away, you was about two yards from the shop—I went out directly.

JOHN STEVENS (police-constable R 55.) The prisoner was given into custody fifteen or twenty yards from the shop—she had these trowsers under her arm, exposed, so that any one could see them—she said they were given her by a gentleman—she appeared to be in liquor, but pre
tended to be so more than she actually was.

Prisoner's Defence. A man gave me the trowsers; he told me to get my
self a pint of beer, and come up the street; I cannot exactly tell the words, for I had been drinking.

GUILTY . Aged 55.—
Confined One Month.

1978.
ALEXANDER STONE was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of June, 1 scythe, value 10s. 6d., the goods of
John Muddle; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1979.
JAMES WHIFFIN was indicted
for obtaining 4 shillings, by false pretences; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

1980.
THOMAS FOUNTAIN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1981.
GEORGE PEAKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of May, 2 biscuits, value 1d. the goods of
Hugh Roberts; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Days, and
Whipped.

1982.
ERASMUS WATSON and
THOMAS ANGELINE were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 18th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 9d., the goods of a man unknown, from his person; to which

WATSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Six Months.

WILLIAM RUSSELL (police-constable C 113.) On the 18th of May I was at Greenwich fair, and saw Watson take this handkerchief from the right-hand pocket of a man who stood looking at Richardson's show, and give it to Angeline—I took Angeline—he dropped it—we called to the gentleman that he had been robbed, but he never came to the station—there was such a crowd, we were pushed away from him directly.

WILLIAM ROMAINE (police-sergeant L 38.) I saw Watson take the handkerchief out of a gentleman's pocket, and give it to Angeline—I took Watson—the gentleman asked for his handkerchief—I told him he must come to the station—he made towards us, but there was a great mob, and we missed him.
Angelines Defence. Watson took the handkerchief, put it into my hand, and I dropped it.
(Angeline received a good character.)

ANGELINE—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Seven Days Solitary, and
Whipped.

1983.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of June, 2 sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Page, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS PAGE . I am a pensioner, living in New-row, Deptford. On Wednesday, the 1st of June, I went to the Royal Charlotte—I had some
thing to drink, and asked the prisoner to partake of a pot of porter—he drank with me—I had about two sovereigns and two shillings in my pocket, when I gave a sovereign to my wife I saw the prisoner wink to another man, and then I told him to leave me—he struck me, and I lost my senses.

JOHN HENRY EDWARDS . I was in the Two Brewers, on Wednesday evening, the 1st of June—I saw the prosecutor come in with a female and a little child—he called for a quart of ale—the prisoner came in—the pro
secutor said, "Get out of my sight"—he gave him a glass of rum, and then the prisoner sat down by the prosecutor, and began to feel his pocket, and said, "You have got plenty of baccay," I then saw him draw out something which looked like a piece of rag—the prosecutor gave a sove
reign to pay for the pot of ale, and then the prisoner took a glass of ale, and dropped it, and broke the glass—the woman said, "You have broken the glass"—he said it was all through that d—d old rogue, and I said, "You have robbed the man," the prisoner up with his hand, and struck the prosecutor in the eye, and then I said, "You rascal, you have robbed him, and now you ill-use him"—the prisoner said, "I will go and pay for the glass," and then he went away, and a policeman was sent for.
Prisoner. Q. Why did not you take me when you saw me take the money? A. I did not know it was money.

KEZIAH DYER . I was at the public-house, and saw the prisoner take and break a glass, then he hit the prosecutor, and took from his pocket a kind of bag, and put it into his own—be hit me, and went out of the house.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not tell persons that you were so drunk you were not capable of seeing any thing? A. No.
JOSEPH GREEN (police-constable R 107.) I told the prisoner I took him for robbing Page of two sovereigns—he said he could always get over such a little job as that.
BENJAMIN LOVELL . (police-constable R 15.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1984.
GEORGE DALTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of June, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Dow
son, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

1985.
PETER DONOHUE and
MICHAEL LANE were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May, 176lbs. weight of lead, value 30s., the goods of
Mary Jane Evelyn and another, and fixed to a building.

JAMES BANKS . I am agent to the Evelyn estate at Deptford—I let the whole of the premises to Mr. George Castles, on a lease for three years—there was a cistern there with lead in it—it was fixed—it belonged to
William John Evelvn, Esq., a minor.
NOT GUILTY .

1986.
FRANCIS WEST was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of May, 261bs. weight of lead, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Elizabeth Valen
tine Aldridge, and fixed to a building.

ANN ELIZABETH KIPPING . I reside at Mount-pleasant, Lewishan, in the house this lead was taken from—the owner is Mrs. Elizabeth Valentine Aldridge, a widow—Mr. Corbett, the agent, put me in the house to take care of it—he did not know Mrs. Aldridge's name till he wrote—I never heard her name but at the office.
JAMES FLUKER was called on his recognizances, and did not answer.
NOT GUILTY .

1987.
ROBERT COULDERY was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of May, 1 purse, value 1d.; 3 shillings, 1 sixpence, 4 pence, and 5 half-pence; the property of
Samuel Hall, from his person.

SAMUEL HALL . I am a Greenwich pensioner. I was in the Infirmary and got leave to go out for a few hours, on the 19th of May—I went to the Red Lion—I had a pint of beer—I paid one shilling, and had sixpence and four penny-pieces in change—I put my beer down in the parlour, and went into the tap-room to light my pipe—I had then 3s. 6d. in silver, four penny-pieces, and 2 1/2 d., in a leather purse, in my waistcoat pocket—probably the string might be hanging out, I cannot say—I was not three minutes gone into the tap—I then returned and drank my beer up—I went out, and did not walk above three yards before I missed my purse—I do not know who took it—I am nearly blind.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you certain you had the purse when you went in? A. Yes—I cannot swear it might not have dropped out of my pocket, but I was not taking any thing out of my pocket—I saw no person near me—I went back to the Infirmary, and on the Sunday following a policeman and Abraham Young came to me.

ABRAHAM YOUNG . I am a dustman. I was at the Red Lion that day, and saw the prisoner take the money out of the prosecutor's waist
coat pocket—it was in a leather bag—I did not say any thing to him—there were two or three more persons with him—I do not know when I first gave information of this—he put it into his pocket—I knew two or three chaps that were there—I heard that one of them had been in Maidstone Goal—I did not see him give any of the money to any person there.
NOT GUILTY .

1988.
JOHN KERRISON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of May, 1 pocket-book, value 1s., the goods of a certain person whose name is unknown.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty in Greenwich fair, about four o'clock, on the 17th of May, and saw the prisoner in com
pany with a boy about eleven years of age—I observed the prisoner cast his eye towards a gentleman's pocket, which drew my attention—I then saw him take the boy, who turned out to be his brother, round to the

gentleman's pocket—the boy turned, and said to the prisoner, "There is nothing there"—they then went on in the fair, from pocket to pocket, of nearly twenty gentlemen, and in some instances the prisoner was not satisfied with the boy trying, but he tried after him—they then went towards the College—there was a mob, and I saw the prisoner take the boy by his two shoulders, turn him round, and tell him to go on—the boy then put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and took out a crust of bread—he looked up in his brother's face, and chucked it up—the little boy then turned to a gentleman, took a pocket-book out of his pocket, and drew it half out—he then dropped it, and ran off—I took the prisoner—I saw the pocket-book half way out of the pocket, in the boy's hand.

Cross-examined by MR. LOCKE. Q. How long have yon been in the police? A. Twelve years and six months—I am well known—I had been in the fair nearly the whole day—I had seen the prisoner for two hours—I was close to him and heard his words—he could see me—he did not know me—I was in plain clothes—I had not blackened my face—I did not know him—he always took the boy by the shoulder and told him to go on—I was so near that I touched him at times—I had a blouse on and a publican's apron—I have seen hundreds and thousands of thieves in aprons—I was close to the gentleman who had the pocket-book—they put their hands into twenty people's pockets—in some the persons moved away or looked at them—I heard them say several times, "Nothing"—I said they tried twenty pockets, but if I should say thirty I should speak under the mark—there were plenty of civilians saw them as well at myself—I did not call on any of them for aid—I believe a brother-officer took the prisoner's brother—I could not find the gentleman who had the book, because the prisoner made off and the gentleman moved away—I made no attempt to speak to him—the book went back into his pocket, and then I ran after them—it was a dark-coloured book—it appeared to me to be a black one—I could not see whether it had a clasp to it—it was six or eight inches long—I looked over his shoulder, and my hand was on his shoulder all the time—it was between five and six o'clock in the evening, and quite light—I do not know whether any one told the gentleman—I certainly was very much out of temper with the prisoner, to see him induce a child to do this—he said, "What do you mean to lay hold of me?"—I said, "I know you are a vagabond and a thief"—he might at once have denied that he had done anything wrong, but I cannot recollect everything he said, or that I said to him.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-sergeant R 122.) I was on duty there, in plain clothes—I saw the prisoner with a little boy—I saw the little boy take a crust of bread from a pocket, and then go to the gentleman, take his pocket-book half-way out, and when he saw he was perceived he dropped it and ran off—we ran after them, thinking the gentleman would follow us—we did not see the gentleman's face.

Cross-examined. Q. What induced you to suppose he would follow you? A. Seeing us make a rush after the prisoner—the gentleman might not have heard or felt anything—there was a great crowd—it was in the street leading to the College—a man was selling knives and other things there were more than a hundred persons all close by the gentleman—the prisoner was taken before the Magistrate, and admitted to bail—we brought another policeman before the Magistrate—he knew the prisoner's brother, but he did not know him.
(Francis Rowles; Thomas Melburn, a coachman; Charles Coring, a waiter at the Spurr-inn, in the Borough; and Jeffry Hammington, a french-polisher; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1989.
JOHN HAYES and
JOHN KIRBY were indicted for
stealing on the 21st of May, l 3/4 lb. weight of cheese, value 1s.; and 3lbs, weight of bread, value 6d.; the goods of
Robert Gibson.

REBECCA JAGGS . I am in the service of Robert Gibson, of Elliott's place, Blackheath. On the 21st of May I missed some bread and cheese from the pantry—I had cut it, and knew it—this now produced is it—they had opened the window to get to the pantry.

ABRAHAM BAYNES (police-constable R 242.) I saw Kirby sitting on the stone at Mrs. Gibson's house—I went towards him, and before I got to him, Hayes came out of the gate with a bundle—I approached them—they ran round the corner—I saw Hayes drop this bread and cheese—a man stopped them—I found on them these blacklead-pencils, which they sell.

HAYES—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

KIRBY—
NOT GUILTY .

1990.
SARAH JOHNS was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of July, 1 bolster, value 5s.; 3 curtains, value 2s.; 2 pillows value 3s.; 2 sheets, value 7s.; 1 table-cover, value 2s. 6d.; 2 table-cloths, value 2s.; 1 looking-glass, value 1s.; and 1 set of fire-irons, value 4s.; the goods of
Harriet George.

HARRIET GEORGE . I am a widow, and live in Blisset-street, Green
wich. On the 14th of July last, I let a room to the prisoner—I missed the articles stated in this indictment from it, which are here, and are my property.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is the prisoner's hus
band's name? A. Watkin Johns—he is now lodging at my house—I let her stay because I had a good opinion of the man—the rent was behind—her husband lived with her when these things were taken—I do not think he knew of it—the prisoner has borne a good character, for what I know.

JOHN SPARKS LOVICK . I am a pawnbroker. I produce a bolster, two sheets, and a set of fire-irons—part of them were pawned by the pri
soner in the name of Johns, and the rest in the same name—I took in the bolster and fire-irons of her.
GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Confined One Month.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

1991.
EDWARD BRAY ,
GEORGE BRAY , and
EDWARD BURKE , were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 1d., the goods of
William Forecast, from his person.

WILLIAM FORECAST . I was at Greenwich-fair, and lost my handker
chief, on the 16th of May—this is it—it is only part of one.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty at Greenwich
fair—I saw all the prisoners in company—I saw Edward Bray take the

handkerchief from the prosecutor, and give it to his brother George, who gave it to Burke—he put it under his jacket, and dropped it—I laid hold of him—I had seen them together for a quarter of an hour or more.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you told all you saw? A. I have not gone through the whole of it—I saw the prisoners first at another man's pocket—I watched them with a brother officer—I told the Magistrate that I had seen them try to pick other people's pockets—they do not always put down what is said.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 122.) I was at the fair—I saw Edward Burke and Edward Bray go find try a pocket—I afterwards saw the prisoners go to the prosecutor—Edward Bray took the handker
chief, gave it to his brother George, and he gave it to Burke.

Cross-examined. Q. How many pockets did you and your friend see them attempt? A. I saw them attempt two or three, but in a crowd a brother officer may see more than I did—I was with Kemp in the fair the whole day, hut he might be standing in the crowd at a short distance the me—we were together when this handkerchief was taken—one of the pri
soners turned and said something before the handkerchief was taken, but I cannot say what it was.
NOT GUILTY .

1992.
CHARLES TREABLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

HENRY POWELL . I am a porter, and live in Compton-street, Bruns
wick-square. I was at Greenwich-fair on the 47th of May—I saw the prisoner put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and take out a silk hand
kerchief—I took him by the collar, and took it not of his hand—at that moment Kemp came up, and I handed him the handkerchief and the pri
soner—there was a mob, and the gentleman was lost sight of—I do not know his name.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was at Greenwich-fair, and saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the gentleman's pocket—the witness took hold of him, and I took him from him—the mob gathered, and we lost the gentleman—I do not know who he was—this is the hand
kerchief.
Prisoner's Defence. Two boys took it, they gave it to me, and ran away.

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Confined Six Months.

1993.
ROBERT ROSS was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of May, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Lee, from his person.

JOHN LEE . I am a seedsman, and live at Islington. I was at Green
wich-fair on the 18th of May—I missed my handkerchief, and this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How do you know it? A. By the pattern, and it is dirty—I had it in my possession two minutes before the policeman informed me I had lost it—I should know it a thousand miles off.

JOHN ARCHER (police-constable G 150.) I was at the fair—I saw the prisoner, and another with him—I saw the prisoner go behind several per
sons,

and try their pockets—at last he got to the prosecutor—he put u hand under his coat, and took the handkerchief out of his left-hand bieii pocket—I saw him put it under his coat—I took him, and tookitfon under his coat.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure you took it from under he coat? A. Yes—the other boy was a little distance from the priso when the handkerchief was taken.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17—
