I am positive it is 400 yards from where Ratcliff says he saw me; I have lived in Clapham nearly six years; he said, "If you offer to take any thing from your pockets I will knock the teeth down your throat;" I never threw any thing from my pockets; there was no place for me to throw any thing away; there are houses on each side

ROBERT RATCLIFF
re-examined. It was not 120 yards from where I saw him.
(Hayes received a good character.

HAYES-
GUILTY . Aged 17.

SCOTT*-
GUILTY Aged 21.
Confined Three Months.

2022.
WILLIAM FAIR was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of June, lib. 3oz. weight of bacon, value 10d., the goods of
George Charles Hunt.

REBECCA HUNT . I am the wife of George Charles Hunt, and keep a chandler's-shop in Rotherhithe. On the 10th of June I saw the prisoner come into the shop, take the bacon off the counter, and put it under his jacket—he went out, I ran after him, and he was taken by the police
man with it.
GUILTY.** Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

2023.
WILLIAM WHITEMAN and
ANN THURSTON
were in
dicted for stealing, on the 10th of November, 1 blanket, value 5s.; 3 sheets, value 85. 6d.; 3 aprons, value 1s.; I petticoat, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; the goods of
Elias Walter .

ELIAS WALTER . I am a miner, living in John's-place, Rotherhithe. In August, 1838, I lived in Adam-street, Rotherhithe—I let Whiteman a furnished room, at 3s. 6d. a-week—he was there about three months—he left the lodging on the 11th of November—I went home, and missed the articles stated—I had seen them safe about half an hour before—Thurston lived with Whiteman as his wife—I saw Whiteman on the 6th of June—I saw Thurston once about two years since—I apprehended her, but could do nothing with her.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How much are you to get for this conviction? A. Nothing—I saw Thurston's husband soon after I took her, and she was discharged because they could not find Whiteman—I made search after him, and gave information—I met him in Lower Deptford-road—his brother and I bad a few words—he came and struck me in the face—I did not make it up—he came afterwards, and put some beer into a pot I was drinking out of—I did not drink it—I put it down—his brother and I had some beer—the prisoner came up and abused me again, and I gave him in charge—I had known his brother seven or eight years—I have asked his brother where he lived—Thurston was abusing my wife, and I gave charge of her—I should have charged her before if I bad found her.

HANNAH WALTER . I am the prosecutor's daughter. The prisoners lodged at my father's, in November, 1838—Thurston left in the morning, and carried a large parcel under her arm—I saw her go out—she did not return again—I did not know but they were her own things. Cross-examined. Q. Did you give evidence before? A. I did not MARIA WALTER. I am the prosecutor's wife. After the prisoners left I found the duplicates in their apartment—I went to the pawnbroker, in Paradise-street, Rotherhithe, and found there two sheets and a blanket—I got them by paying half-a-crown.

JOHN KNIGHT (police-constable M 250.) In consequence of informa
tion, I took Whiteman on the 6th of June—he asked what I wanted with him—I said, "On suspicion of robbery"—the prosecutor was with me, and gave him into custody—he said twenty more policemen should not take him, and when we got to the Jolly Soldiers he knocked me down—he said he was innocent.
NOT GUILTY .

2027.
ELIZABETH FIELD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

2028.
WILLIAM COOK was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of May, 1 brass bearing-cap, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Grissell and another.

JAMES WALKER . I am an ironmonger, in the service of Thomas Gris
sell and Mr. Peto, and live in Newport-street, Lambeth. I have missed some new bearing-caps from their premises—I saw this one—it corre
sponds with such as we have in our possession—I partly believe it to be ours—I have no private mark on it—it has been broken.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You would not swear is it? A. No—I have known the prisoner two or three years—he has been with us three months, and has conducted himself well.
JONES JONES . I am clerk to Grissell and Peto. On the 25th of May I saw the prisoner leave the premises to go to dinner—I watched him to Salter's marine-store shop, in Lambeth-marsh.

WILLIAM ADAMS . I was at the marine-store dealer's—I purchased this piece of metal of a man that day for 8d., in the name of John Jones, Felix-street, but I could not swear to the prisoner—the policeman stopped me with it.
Cross-examined. Q. Is this brass or copper? A. It is pot-metal, not brass—this cannot be sold for brass.

MARY TAYLOR . I am a marine-store dealer, in Upper Marsh, Lam. beth. About eight o'clock at night I bought this bit of brass of a man, but I do not know the man—I told the Magistrate so—I might say I be
lieved the prisoner was the person.
Cross-examined. Q. Was this the small piece you purchased? A. I cannot swear that this is the piece—I gave 8d. for it.
THOMAS GOOSE (police-constable L 160.) I took the prisoner, and have the metal.
NOT GUILTY .

2029.
THOMAS WEBB was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of June, 4 spoons, value 2l. 18s.; and 3 thimbles, value 2s.; the goods of
Mary Webb and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

2030.
RICHARD CLOSE and
FREDERICK MADDOX were
indicted for stealing, on the 27th of May, 1 copper boiler, value 5l. and I copper arm of a still, value 1l.; the goods of
John Marks; and
CHARLES BURNEY
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ALFRED PHILLIPS . I am a carman, and live in Long-lane, Bennond
sey. In consequence of directions from Mr. John Marks, I went to a person named Jones, in Rosemary-lane, and got a copper boiler—I put it into my stable—it was safe there about eleven o'clock on Thursday night. the 26th of May, and it was missed at ten minutes past seven' on the Fri
day morning—I know Maddox—Close keeps a horse and cart in our yard—I have since seen the arm of a boiler, and, to the best of my belief, it is part of the boiler we lost that night—it is the property of John Marks. o

JOHN WARD . On the morning of the 27th of May I was in the back
room at Mr. Burney's, talking to the child—this copper was put into the shop, but I cannot say by whom—Burney was not at home—I went and put the copper into the back-place—I then went out, and saw Close in a cart, driving off—there were several other carts in the street—Burney came in afterwards at the back-door.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. The policeman caught you with the copper on you? A. I was taking it to the back-place, to show Mrs. Burney, as there was no one in the place but her—I am a labourer, and corn or coal-porter—I never was in prison.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you work for Mr. isaacs? A. Yes—he is a marine-store dealer—I went to the Cherry Tree that morn
ing, and saw Burney there, drinking with a policeman who was off duty—I told him I wanted him to come and load a cart of rags for me—he said he would.

GEORGE POTTER (police-constable M 39) A few minutes after eight o'clock, on the morning of the 27th of May, I was going by Mr. Burney's door, promiscuously, and saw a chocolate-coloured cart—there was no one in it—I went into the shop—Burney met me, and I said, "What is up now?"—he said, "Nothing much"—I said, "What is that; is it all right?"—he said, "Ob, I will make it all right with you; no one saw it come in but you"—I said, "What is it?"—I went to the back part of the shop, and saw it was part of a copper still—I said, "You can't make it right with me; you must go to the station, and make it right at the sta
tion"—he said, "Well, if you mean that, you had better stop; the man will be back in half-an-hour; I have not paid him; he is coming back for the money"—I said, "Very well, I will stop"—I stopped five or ten minutes above half an hour—I then said it was useless waiting any longer, and I took Burney to the station—in the afternoon I took Ward, who was carrying the copper through the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. DO you live near Burney? A. Yes, within about 100 yards—I did not notice any person present but Barney's wife, when I had this conversation with him—I believe this it part of a still.

THOMAS WEST (police-conskible M 249.) On the meming of the 27th, about twenty minutes past six o'clock, I was on duty, about half-a-mile from Phillips's—I met Maddox and Close going towards Burney's house, in a direction from Phillips's—and about fifteen-yards behind them I saw a chocolate-coloured cart, and a person was driving it who frequents the Kent-road—I should know him if I saw him.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you know the yard that Phil
lips speaks of? A. Yes—I have seen three or four carts about there—I know Maddox—I had not seen Close before.
THOMAS BRYANT . I am a general dealer. I lent Close a chocolate-coloured cart, on the 27th of May, to go to Epsom—he was to return it the next day—I found it again on Saturday morning.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you go to Epsom yourself? A. Yes—I saw Close in my cart, on this side of Ewell, which is fourteen miles from Cornhill—and I saw him at Epsom—he had his own horse in my cart—his horse is a slow one.
NOT GUILTY .

2031.
MARY JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of June, 1 razor, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Benjamin Fisher.

BENJAMIN FISHER . I am a hair-dresser, and live at Rotherhithe. The prisoner came to my shop, on the morning of the 15th of June, about a quarter before seven o'clock—when she was gone I missed this rasor.

WILLIAM MOBB (police-constable M 273.) I was in the Jolly Water
man on that morning, about seven o'clock—the prisoner came in, walked
to the end of the counter, took something from her pocket, and put it under the beer-engine.
THOMAS WILEY (police-constable M 25.) I took the prisoner—I looked under the engine, and found this razor.
Prisoner's Defence, I do not remember having it.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.
